section.title: Introduction
section.para: With the completion of increasing numbers of genome sequences has come an explosion in the development of both computational and experimental high-throughput techniques for deciphering the functions of molecules and their interactions. However, many of these data are noisy and stronger inferences can be made if one is able to combine data from different sources. Currently, biological data are stored in a wide variety of formats in numerous different places, making complex queries across these data sources hard. One of the current challenges for bioinformatics is therefore to develop resources for the integration and combined analysis of such data. The FlyMine project is an open-source project to build an integrated database of genomic, expression and proteomics data for Drosophila, Anopheles and other insects.

The FlyMine database is built using InterMine, an open-source data warehouse system for integrating the data from many sources into one object-based database. The FlyMine data model is generated by merging existing and emerging ontologies and standards (e.g. MAGE, SO, PSI), thus enabling data to be loaded from a variety of sources and providing the flexibility to easily incorporate new data sources as they appear. A powerful and flexible query interface to these data enables users to perform arbitrary and complex queries across the data either via a web interface or a programming interface. The web interface enables users to build queries, by combining classes of objects and applying constraints to their attributes. Queries and sets of results can be saved for use in further queries or for feeding to analysis programs. The result display includes links to external databases, class and attribute browsing capability as well as the ability to select data for download in a variety of formats. Display and analysis tools will be available soon. Help is available through query examples, on-line help pages and an analysis support help-desk.

The first release of FlyMine includes genome annotation data for Drosophila melanogaster and Anopheles gambiae, yeast 2-hybrid data for D. melanogaster and C. elegans, and orthologue/ paralogue data relating the genes of these organisms. The inclusion of Caenorhabditis elegans orthologues also gives access to C. elegans RNAi phenotypes. Development of the database is currently rapid. We aim to add new functional genomics data sources and increase coverage to further insects as data become available, as well as maintaining continued development of the web interface and analysis tools. We hope that FlyMine will become a valuable data mining tool for the insect genomics community.
